Jun 24 2006	An excellent hotel - no major complaints.	The Homewood Suites is a Hilton all-suites property located in a near-perfect location, tucked away in a retail area a couple of blocks away from Michigan Ave. There's not a grand entrance, but a small entryway that holds the elevators to go up to the lobby (6th floor; rooms are floors 7-19, which does lead to some reduction of street noise), some brochures and a few other odds and ends.The lobby area is actually quite lovely, with a "lodge"-like feeling that doesn't come off as impersonal and forced (in other words, it doesn't feel like a generic, chain attempt at a lodge feel.) There's cozy, plush couches in the lobby area and free coffee/tea available while you wait. The reception desk is at the end of the lobby and holds about two or three check-in desks. I was a little surprised, as while I was there on a fairly quiet day, I have to imagine that, with only a few check-in counters, there is a fairly decent line at times. Check-in was pleasant and uneventful (we did have to wait a few minutes, but that was understandable, as there'd been a convention in town that wrapped the night before), although the check-in time is a bit dismaying - a rather late 4pm.for a room.The room assigned was right by the elevator, but I didn't complain, as I'd paid less than half the $200-a-night price by luckily finding the hotel on Hotwire. There were a couple of instances where the elevator opening could be heard, but it was truly minor and really couldn't even be heard when the TV was on.The rooms themselves are quite nice, as the 1 bedroom rooms offer a large, open kitchen area, a living room with couch/chair and TV, bedroom w/additional TV, dressing area w/sink and finally, additional small area w/toilet and shower. The kitchen area is fully stocked, with dishes and some pots and silverware. There's also a dishwasher, microwave, oven, frig, plenty of cabinet space and small dining room table. The refrigerator has an ice maker in the freezer, so you don't have to wander down the hall. There's also a coffee machine.As for the refrigerator, there's a Jewel grocery store on State St. a few blocks from the hotel (half a block North of the corner of State/Grand, West side of the St.)Additionally, all of these things aren't jammed up together - there's quite a bit of space between the kitchen area and living room area. Didn't try the high-speed internet, but the sign noted it was now complimentary and there was an outlet right next to the dining room table/desk.The TV offered plenty of channels and the usual assortment of pay-per-view movies. Shower offered 4 different settings and the bathroom area was clean and generally well-maintained. Toilet was a tad noisy w/the tank refilling, but otherwise everything was fine. Overall, the room was fresh and new. The refrigerator was spotless inside and the entire kitchen area looked crisp and clean. Aside from what appeared to be a small drink spill stain on the rug that was barely noticable, the room did not seem worn in any way. The hotel was built in 1999, but 7 years has not seemed to do much to it, as it looked even a little fresher than that.The room didn't offer too much of a view (pretty, but nothing too astonishing), but given the location, I don't think any of the rooms in the building are going to offer too great a view, although some of the higher ups may be better off. You're definitely not going to be looking at a brick wall, but I think it's generally a look across at the nearby buildings, as well as some views of the surrounding area. The pool area on the top floor was quite pretty - not a giant pool, but a nice enough one that provided a pretty nice view of the surrounding area. There is also a mid-sized fitness room on that floor, as well. A very small laundry room is on the 7th floor. There's a small gift shop area next to the reservations desk.Homewood does also offer breakfast every morning from 7-10; there's a nice selection of eggs, meat, breads, pastries, cereal, juice, pop (because Diet Coke is part of a balanced breakfast, at least according to me) and more. What really surprised me was the extent of the area - the dining area is quite large and quite lovely; there's quite a bit of seating and you don't feel as if you're crammed in.Additionally, the hotel does serve a dinner reception from Monday-Thursday. Didn't try it as I was there on a Friday, but was impressed with the wide variety of options offered (there's a different kind of food each day, noted on the calendar on the refrigerator in the room.)Those who don't want to be in a hotel where there's a lot of kids running around being loud and unsupervised are probably not going to find that here. While family-friendly, the way that the hotel is set-up doesn't allow for a lot of run-around room and I'm guessing that more families opt for either of the nearby Embassy Suites properties. While I did like staying at the Marriott Residence Inn (another all-suites property downtown) a bit North of this hotel (the Residence by Water Tower Mall), this hotel seems much fresher and more modern and has more to offer.That said, I really did like this hotel a great deal. It's kept up well, comfortable, has a very nice staff, big rooms and a terrific location that is very close to Michigan Ave. without being right on it. There's also a subway a few blocks away at State/Grand. Definitely a good choice for families or travelers who are looking for additional amenities (kitchen, breakfast) and more space.

Jun 10 2006 	Perfect hotel!	This was my third trip to Chicago and I finally found the perfect hotel! The location is excellent, walking distance to many sights and great shopping. Abundant restaurant choices within a few blocks. I was there for the GlobalComm conference and the shuttle buses to McCormick Place picked us up everyday right around the corner. I would advise against valet parking. The rates for that are very expensive, but a car is not necessary anyway. Our room was one of the smaller suites, but very cozy and well-appointed. The cleanliness was impeccable. The staff was friendly, efficient, and helpful. It was so convenient to have the full kitchen, complete with dishes, utensils, etc. Housekeeping even empties the icemaker before you check-in, so you get fresh ice. Housekeeping loaded and ran the dishwasher everyday. Fresh linens and towels were given everyday. The king bed was very comfortable with fitted sheets! Hotel beds with all flat sheets are a pet peeve of mine. Towels were thick and soft. Very nice pool on the top floor with a great view. We were on the 11th floor overlooking Nordstroms. We left the curtains open at night and the lights of the surrounding tall buildings made a nice nightlight. The free hot breakfast was phenominal...eggs, bacon, waffles, potatoes, all sorts of pastries, fruit, etc. It was great to get take-out trays and eat in the comfort of our room. We didn't try the evening manager's reception, but I will endeavor to do that next time. Wireless internet worked great on my Mac laptop. I was disappointed that no one helped with our luggage when we arrived, but they made up for it on our way out, watching for our airport shuttle and handling the baggage for us. I recommend the Cosi Restaurant across the street for lunch. Mary's Cafe down Grand Ave on the other side of Michigan is good if you don't want the hotel breakfast. Buca's Italian Restaurant on the corner is excellent, inexpensive, and very friendly. Overall, I couldn't have found a better place to stay.

Jun 8 2006 	Good location wonderful breakfast	Stayed here on a Thu/Fri for a business conference. Great location - lots of restaurants and shopping within an easy walk. Hard to find when driving - sign is not very big at all. Valet parking is a deal - only $1/day more than parking myself - definitely worth it.Carpeting in room was a bit shabby, but bed was excellent and everything seemed clean. I did not use the kitchen except to keep some drinks cold, but everything appeared to be in good shape.I did not try the evening meal (only available the Thu I was there), but I did eat breakfast both mornings and it was VERY nice. You could make your own waffles, plus cereal, pastries, sausage, eggs, corned beef hash one morning, etc. Also fruit, juices, toast, yogurt, potatoes, etc, etc. It was the nicest included breakfast I've had in a while.Staff were very friendly, room was very quiet and had good drapes for blocking the city lights.Were I looking for something in that area again, I would definitely stay there.

May 29 2006	We Love Homewood Suites	We stayed at the Homewood Suites on May 26 and May 27,2006 and absolutely loved it. The location was close to everything we wanted to do,the bed was fantastic,the staff extremely accomadating and the price comparable to other hotels nearby. We paid $199/Night. It was very convenient having the kitchenette at our disposal. We went to a nearby store(White Hen) and bought snacks, Milk, Pop,etc and had our refridgerator and microwave at our fingertips. The big surprise was the free breakfast in the morning. They told us there was a buffet breakfast,but we thought cereal and donuts. We were pleasantly surprised to find a full breakfast with eggs,potatoes, ham ,biscuits and gravy, juice,cereal ,everything we could possibly want....Our suite was pleasant and impeccably clean. We will definately stay there again .

May 26 2006	Yuck!	My Dad booked us a hotel in chicago, I let him because he loves using the internet to save money. This time, we arrived at a dirty, tiny, almost falling apart suite for a week. We paid $350/ night and it was a stupid waste of money, The sheets were old and crusty and the blankets were coming apart. The kitchen was old and moldy. I hated it.Good luck!

May 12 2006 	Reliable Hilton-Brand Lodging	Stayed here on business May 4. Also scouting for a family trip in August and this is the nicest of the three suite type hotels I visited. The Hilton quality control is evident in staff appearance and behavior, clean comfortable rooms, and create an overall good feeling about the hotel. Living room is a little tight in the suite (if the sofa bed were folded out it would be against the TV screen, the room is that narrow). Kitchenette is a nice touch and bedroom and bath were nice. Didn't avail myself of the breakfast or evening food/drink but that is a nice touch also. Rates vary: I paid $245 on this Thursday business stay but booked rooms for $170 for a Wed-Sun stay in August for my family, so check different dates, AAA discount, etc. to get best rate. Hotel is next to the train station for sightseeing.

May 7 2006 	Great affordable hotel especially for a conference stay	I recently spent three nights here (should have been four, had it not been for airline problems) and was very pleased with the quality of the stay and especially with the kindness of everyone I encountered there. Although our rooms weren't ready when we checked in, we were given a bottle of wine and were treated very well. I happened to know that the hotel was fully booked due to a huge conference and I thought the hotel staff handled it very well. The breakfast was a full, hot breakfast and was very good. We didn't take advantage of the free dinner, etc. Our rooms were clean and in very good shape. They were sufficient for our stay and were very comfortable. This isn't high-end sophisticated romantic luxury stuff......but is great for a shopping or business trip. Location is terrific.

May 1 2006	a real gem but shop for best rates	This was quite the find in Chicago. Good location (across the street from Nordstroms), hot breakfast included and clean & quiet. The place was full of families and travelling school groups but we never heard any noise. Not the place for an intimate rendezvous! We had an amazing rate in January - when we went to stay again in April it was triple the price.

Apr 28 2006	Good value nice location	Our family of four stayed three nights and were very satisfied overall. Good location in town walking distance to Michigan Avenue shops, John Hancock Building, Navy Pier, free trolley and other public transportation. Rooms and public areas were clean with nice decor and great views. It was slightly less expensive than other area hotels, and the free breakfast made it an even better value. Food at the weekday "dinner" was mediocre, but we enjoyed having a free beer or soda and chips during that time. Free high speed internet access worked well, and complimentary admission to the Crunch Fitness next door (including classes) was the icing on the cake. Rooms on the small side even though we had a larger 1 BR suite. Not enough storage for a group of four (one three-drawer dresser and a closet with 10 hangers). Kids enjoyed pool on top floor - great views. Only real complaint - we had our bags held after check out while we did some sightseeing, and were assured they would be placed in a secured area. When we returned hours later, they were behind the bellman's stand in the first floor entrance area - not exactly what I'd consider secure considering it is open to the public and not always attended. Fortunately, nothing was stolen and we had a laptop in one of the suitcases.
Mar 8 2006	great stay	Clean rooms, Great breakfast, Friendly staff, Great location,Nice pool(a bit small but it's a pool)I would recommend this hotel to anyone.

Jan 1 2006	Pool and a Hot Breakfast make this hotel stand out!	This hotel is a pretty good value. We had a king bed in the bedroom, a large bathroom, and a living room/kitchen with a pull-out sleep sofa that was actually comfortable. The kids loved the cookies, bottled water, and popcorn they give to their guests. The location is excellent. Bloomingdales, Nordstrom, ESPN Zone, and several great restaurants are within a few blocks. A free trolley runs to Navy Pier. There are a few drawbacks that have been mentioned earlier. DO NOT USE THE VALET PARKING!!! Some things we put in our storage compartment were scattered on the floor of our van. Forunately we didn't leave anything of value in our van and haven't noticed anything missing yet.

Dec 15 2005	Best value downtown	Stayed at the Homewood suites for a weekend (Nov 11) and it was just fine. Good location, good condition, clean large rooms, very nice having a kitchen and separate rooms. No complaints at all. I'd stay there again anytime.

Nov 14 2005 	Best Overall Value without major sacrifices	This is the best value for the dollar of any downtown hotel, and that's coming from a pickey,critical and frugal traveler. I will try to stay there whenever I'm in Chicago again - and I researched tons of places. The good: 1.Prior to check in I had requested a corner room 'X18' as all the '18's' are corners. Check in was smooth but room wasn't what I'd requested. I called the desk and they changed the room right away without any hastles. Had 2 great views of downtown lights and it was quiet 2. The room was clean on arrival, cleaned properly daily (I leave small coins around to see how good the cleaning crew is), and the linen was changed daily (I put little "x's" on the corners - told you I was pickey).3.New soaps daily too.4 large refrigerator for ice and leftovers. 5. staff was friendly and willing to help with directions and suggestions of where to buy things from wine to restaurants to take out. 6. location great - I could walk everywhere downtown, but not to the convention center 7. the breakfast provided was really very nice and included everything - eggs, cereal, yogert, fruit, juices, breads/rolls/bagels/etc., coffee, skim milk, tea, etc. with bananas,oranges,apples you could take out (for lunch).You could even get a take out plate to fill up with breakfast if you wanted to take it back to your room! 8.the afternoon/early evening food included beer/wine/sodas + snacks + light dinner, like baked potatoes with your choice of multiple toppings for example. You could really altogether avoid restaurants if you wanted to. 9. both elevators worked fine. The downside - well,1. the bathrooms are tile and not travertine marble and there's no phone by the side of the toilet 2. the shower head was about 7' high and the rotating pulser didn't work well on all settings 3. the bedroom is small - I could stand on the bed and reach 3 of the 4 walls. 4. sitting area had couch, chair, coffee table, TV on stand, writing desk and chair but was on the small side 5. decoration with silk ivy plants is not to my taste. None of the negatives were very egregious in my book.

Oct 30 2005	BEWARE of the valet service	I stayed there for 2 days/3nights and had parked my car in the valet service. It was a nice hotel but when it came to getting my car out my watch was missing. The managers, well 1 of 5, tried to help me but the others were inconsiderate. They said there was nothing I could do except file a complaint. I did that and 2 months later still nothing. I for one will never go back to this hotel. It was very disappointing that the valet service would steal your precious belongings.

Oct 10 2005	Very nice downtown hotel	The Homewood is an excellent choice if you are going to be staying in downtown Chicago. All hotels are expensive in the city, but you get a lot for your money here. The suites are spacious, with a full kitchen, desk, couch, and television in the entry room, and then a separate bedroom with very large attached bathroom. As others have mentioned, the lobby to the hotel is actually on the sixth floor, but the friendly valets will direct you up there. Since all the rooms are on upper floors, you should have some kind of view of the city from every room. They serve a light "dinner" in the evening, and then a hot breakfast buffet in the morning with eggs, biscuits and gravy, bacon, sausage, etc. And unlike most free hotel breakfasts, they have servers bring coffee for you! The location is quite good, with a train stop right across the street. The Homewood is right in one of the main shopping districts of Chicago as well, with Nordstrom directly across the street and many other stores and restaurants within very short walking distance. It doesn't necessarily have the feel of a "five-star" hotel, but if our experience was representative, you should expect a very nice stay at a reasonable value.

Sep 20 2005	Good location family orientation	If you're visiting Chicago with a family, this is a perfect place to stay. You'll have room to spread out and many Chicago attractions are within walking distance. The entrance is hard to spot from the street and is very cramped. That's because the lobby, which is very spacious and welcoming, is actually on the second floor. There are only two elevators, which were usually crowded because of the number of families staying. We had to get adjoining suites because no two-bedroom accomodations were available. (This seemed unusual to us.) However, the hotel was very helpful in making sure our suites were next to each other, which was quite an accomplishment over Labor Day weekend. You'll be a couple of blocks from the free trolley - a great way to get to the loop - and Pizzaria Uno is right across the street. You can put your name in, go back and relax, and show up for your pizza an hour and a half later. Everything, including lodging, is expensive in Chicago but this is worth it.

Aug 29 2005	Great deal and location for families	I stayed here with my husband and 2 children ( 4 and 1) for 2 nights recently. It was a perfect location, close to the free trolley and regular bus lines, a couple blocks from Michigan Ave, right in the middle of the downtown area.The kitchen area was great - full size fridge, oven, microwave and a dishwasher. We did not have any problems with noise, and the living room area was big enough to pull out the sofa bed for my 4 year old and set up the pack-n-play for my 1 year old with no problem at all. The free breakfast was good -- several options, eggs, french toast, potatoes, several cold danish/doughnut selections, cereal, fruit, etc. We didn't have trouble either morning getting a table, but as others have said, you can also get takeout containers and take it back to your room. I'd definitely recommend this hotel to families and anyone looking for a good deal on a hotel in the heart of downtown. We will definitely stay again when we return to Chicago.

Jul 23 2005	Home(wood) away from Home	We had reservations at Hilton Garden Inn over July 4 weekend but due to a flight delay we were moved to The Homewood Suites. The rooms were good size, very clean and super quiet. The staff was courteous and helpful. The location was perfect. We were able to walk most everywhere we wanted to go, including Grant Park, the Museums, Navy Pier, shopping, and restaurants.The price was reasonable and included a breakfast buffet each morning. On Sunday the wait was quite long for a table but we were provided with carry out containers and enjoyed it in our suite. Elevator waits could be long when large groups were checking in. I chose to take the stairs (to the 19th floor) rather than wait.Great view from our room.

Jul 21 2005	Great stay at Homewood	My husband and I stayed at the Homewood Suites Mon-Wed the 2nd week in July. The location is superb. The free breakfast hit the spot each morning, even had to-go boxes to bring it back up to our room. Having a fridge, microwave, dishwasher and stove made it more "homey" for us. We popped popcorn one evening (complimentary) too. $35 a day to park was the only drawback. I would definitely go back.

Jul 9 2005	"5 Star" In my book!!!	Absolutely nothing to complain about. Location was #1. Talk about convenience. Trolley to Pier right outside your door. From O'Hare we got off the red line, went up the steps and our hotel was right there. Shopping and Mich Ave is just steps away. Facility is new and pristine. Our suite was on the 17th floor. Large, spacious and spotless with a gorgeous view of the Wrigley Building and the Chicago River. The furniture is all brocade and the carpet is beautifully carved. I never heard of a hotel offering a full hot breakfast with everything you can imagine, to a full dinner in the evening (Mon-Thur) including beer, wine, and dessert. The pool is a large olympic size lap pool with ample towels and bowls of fruit everywhere. The building is very upscale with an outside doorman and bellman. Free internet service and our suite was so quiet I felt like I was in a soundproof room because the A/C is almost silent and works very well. What more can you ask for. People who find fault with the hotel have to get their head examined because this facility is flawless. I will always come here when I stay in Downtown Chicago. The service is excellent and front desk is extremely respectful and friendly. I work in the hospitality industry and wish that all my encounters were as pleasant as this at The Homewood Suites. Very well run! Thank You

Jul 5 2005 	Good Hotel with a Few Problems	Stayed at the Homewood Suites for one week in late June/early July 2005, at a price of $149. per night. This all-suite hotel has an excellent location two blocks from Michigan Ave. and two blocks from a subway stop. Shopping and restuarant choices are within easy walking distance. The hotel occupies the 6th-19th. floor, and I very strongly recommend asking for a room on floors 15-19 for the view as well as the noise reduction at those heights. (Do NOT get stuck in suites 706 or 708. Both these rooms are adjacent to the hotel's one coin-op laundry room for guests. By the way, the washers and dryers worked very well!) Homewood offers a good hot breakfast buffet, but it can get crowded at times. Each suite includes a full-size refrigerator and a mike in a separate kitchen area. The shallow pool on the 19th floor is also very nice - the area has stunning views of The Loop. The room air conditioning also worked very well and was rather quiet. Problems with the hotel and my stay in it included: long waits for the two elevators; minor problems with the maid service; and a stains on the rapidly ageing carpet and furniture. Also, the mattress, pillows and bed linens were subpar - even for an older budget hotel. Please be aware thateach "suite" is only large enough to comfortably accomodate 2-4 persons. You should be able to get a good deal at this hotel - there were many empty rooms during my stay. Their business seems to largely depend on tour groups and conventioneers.Recommended - with a few reservations - to those on a budget.

Jul 5 2005	Excellent stay at the Homewood Chicago	We visited Chicago the last week of June 2005, decided to extend our stay for a couple of days. The Hilton was full due to the July 4 weekend crowds, but the registration clerk at the Hilton suggested and booked the Homewood suites. This was an excellent find for us. We had a two room suite with a kitchenette. The beds were BIG and comfortable, lobby nice and service excellent, even though the hotel was very full. The pool was really nice also- glass enclosed on the nineteenth floor with an excellent view. Breakfast was included. We had an excellent rate of $189, but I think that it was the weekend rate. I think this was a real great stay, especially if you are traveling with kids and want more space than just a hotel room provides.

Jul 5 2005	Great location / OK hotel	We stayed at the Homewood Suites for 3 nights over the 4th of July weekend. The location of the hotel is excelllent. It is two blocks from Michigan Avenue. There is a subway (red line) one block west. The room size was OK. The configuration of the room was not great. Access to the bathroom was through the main bedroom which is not the best setup if you have a family. The Embassy Suites that I have stayed in have the bathroom with a separate entrance which is a better setup. There is some kind of problem with the water system in the hotel. It was very noisy (loud clunking and banging) when guests were using their showers or bathrooms. This was not wonderful when the folks next door were using their shower at 3:30AM. The hotel was pretty busy and there was a long wait for the elevators on occasion. There is a great Crunch gym next door which is free to hotel guests. The pool in the hotel was very nice. Overall it was an OK stay but it definitely could have been better.

Jun 2 2005	A Great Place for Families	This hotel is great for families, especially with young kids, especially those on a budget, because it has:1. A nice swimming pool. #1 on the kid satisfaction list.2. Free, full breakfasts seven days per week with a variety of hot and cold foods.3. Free "business receptions" Mon-Thurs evenings. What that really means is a free, hot buffet supper (choices more limited, sometimes less tasty than breakfast).4. Full kitchens in the room with microwave, stove, dishwasher, sink and real (empty! no mini-bar!) refrigerator. 5. A very nice city grocery store (Osco/Jewel) only two blocks away to stock your kitchen (if you want). 6. A separate bedroom for mom and dad. We pulled the mattress out of the fold-out couch in the "living room" and put it on the floor. Our two young kids enjoyed "camping out," everyone got a good night's sleep, and didn't all have to go to bed at the same time or get up at the same time. 7. A great location: two blocks west of Michigan Ave shopping and bus service, one-two blocks south of "Restaurant Row," and one block north of the east-west bus to Navy Pier.8. Free wireless internet access.9. Small workout room in hotel, plus free access to large workout facility ("Crunch") next door (get away from kids while they swim with other parent.)10. Nice, basic clean rooms. Once you pay the room rate (about $200) and the garage fee ($35), your other costs are totally under your control: eat hotel food, eat your food, eat out cheap or eat out well. Use your car, take the bus, take a cab, take a train, ride a boat. With the free breakfast, you can get the kids up, going, fed and to a museum on the bus by 10 am.The Homewood Suites can be your "home away from home," but it's not the place for a honeymoon (with a kitchen! Get real!) or a romantic getaway or a place that caters to your every whim. Bring your guidebook or your computer and do your homework. Recommendations:Get a CTA Visitor Transit Pass (2, 3 or 5-day) at the Marriott Hotel gift shop next door. Get a transit map or print one out from the computer.Have a Lincoln Park Zoo day: take bus 146 from Michigan Ave. to the Lincoln Park Zoo. Walk the zoo, the farm, the Conservatory and the Cuthbaert Nature Museum (with the butterfly room). Then go to the nice playground across the street and one block south from the main entrance to the zoo to wear out your kids for a good night's sleep.The Wendella Tours boat dock is only four blocks from the hotel where Michigan Ave. meets the river.

Apr 25 2005	Great Price and Location	My wife, 2.5 year old son and I traveled to Chicago on vacation from 4/14-4/21/05 and stayed the seven days at the Homewood Suites. It was perfect for us. Like other suites we have stayed in (i.e. Residence Inn, Hawthorne Suites, etc.) the suite had a small kitchen, living room and bedroom. Our son stayed in the living room on the sofa-sleeper while my wife and I stayed in the room. It was very private and worked out great. The room had a good view of the river and the River North. The location was great, close to Michigan Ave and shopping as well as various restaurants, including Joe's Steak and Crab, Pizzeria Uno, ESPN Zone, etc. The Red line (i.e. subway or "L") was only about a block away. Moreover, the great thing about the hotel was that they provided breakfast 7 days a week and from M-Th dinner as well. The best thing about this aspect is that they provided take out boxes if you wanted to bring the food up to your room! That was very convenient something that I never received at either Hawthorne Suites or at the Residence Inn. What I would do is wake up and go down and bring up food for my wife and son while they continued to rest. Please note that although the staff was generally nice and attempted to be helpful, this is NOT the Four Seasons so don't expect it to be. For example, the staff does not make reservations at restaurants, but will give you the phone number. Again, for the price ($139/nt, a discount if you stay at least 7 nights), it wasn't that big a deal anyway. The telephone system worked out well, too. They do not charge if you are dialing a number in that particular area code (i.e. within the loop). If I visit Chicago again, I would definitely stay at and recommend the Homewood Suites.Also, I would recommend taking the subway from O'Hare to the hotel. You would take the blue line (the entrance is right at the baggage area, if flying AA) transfer to the red line at, I believe, Washington, going North, and two stops later you get off and walk to the hotel a block. The only issue is that with a young child, it was a little bit of a walk going down stairs through a long tunnel and back up some stairs on the transfer, but for $1.75 a person (verses $35 for a taxi) you can't beat the price! Also the subway is fun for the kids. Just be careful about various individuals traveling the subway, like any other big city. Watch your bags, wallets, etc.As for getting around the city, overall, I realize that Chicago is not that convenient a city to get around. It is actually fairly confusing. The subways don't really go near many of the museums. The bus seems a bit more convenient, but the system is a bit confusing. Taxi apparently is one big way to travel, but the cost can be an issue. We found walking to be fun and rather enjoyable, albeit tiring, but it was a nice way to get familiar with the city. As for restaurants, I would recommend Joe's Steak and Crab. Very good food, nice service. Our waiter was Scott and he treated us well. We also ate at Morton's and I believe that Joe's was by far a better steak place and the price was a little better. As for pizza's I personally liked Pizzeria Uno, it was very very convenient as for the location. Just be prepared to wait for a table or for pizza about an hour. My wife liked Lou Minati (sp?). We didn't particularly like Gino's East as much. The pizza was so so and the price was about $5 more. As for museums, we got the city pass and actually went to all 6 destinations. The best museum for kids was the Museum of Industry and Science. To get there, we took the Metra which was $2.05. We would walk down Michigan Ave to the Metra station right across from the Cultural Center and got a ticket. Just remember the Metra is similar to Amtrak and that there are certain times that the train comes. It is NOT like the subway. So we had to wait about 45 minutes to get on one of the trains. It dropped you off about .5 miles from the Museum (I cannot recall the actual Avenue to take...59th?) and it was a nice short walk. The museum is great for kids who enjoy trains, airplanes, etc. My son loves trains and they have an incredible toy train system going as well as two other trains within the museum. You could spend a number of hours at the museum so plan accordingly.Museums that I did not particularly like was the Adler Planetarium, rather boring. The Aquarium was nice for kids as well. I would say that it was probably comparable with the Monterey Bay Aquarium. The dolphin show is okay. Field Museum was okay. Probably better for older kids. I was surprised in seeing that their dinosaur exhibit was just okay. Sue was nice to see (the T-rex), but other than that, they didn't have much else in the way of dinosaurs. I did feel, however, that the Field was better than the Natural History Museum in New York. The actual exhibits seemed more up to date than that of the NHM in New York. The Art Institute really is not for kids. We went there and my son did well, but he got bored pretty quickly. The Hancock Observatory is nice as well. The dates we went to these museums, there were no lines and we had a great time overall.As for other things to see and do, I would recommend the Wrigley Field tour, neat inside look of the stadium. You get to check out the locker rooms, dugouts, field, press box, bleachers, etc. We also took the Wendela cruise line that takes you onto the lake and on the Chicago River and that was great. The cost for the 90 minute tour is the same as the 60 minute tour and it takes you onto Lake Michigan. I would recommend this. The cost was $19 a person. Another great place to take the time out for is the Lincoln Zoo. It's actually a very nice well kept zoo and it also is free! To be quite honest, I've been to the San Diego Zoo a number of times, and although the SD Zoo is much larger, I actually prefer the Lincoln Zoo. The size is not as huge, the atmosphere is actually nicer and it is pretty kid friendly. To get to Lincoln Park, however, is a bit difficult, so I would recommend the bus. the subway goes nowhere near this location. You could walk, but that is a pretty difficult trek from the River North.One further thing to note when traveling with kids, child seats are apparently required. So if you plan on taxi or renting a car, keep this in mind. That's one of the reasons why we walked a lot and took the bus or subway. Seven days is a good amount of time in Chicago. If we had another 2-3 days we would have had the chance to take a look at Oak Park (home of one of the Frank Lloyd Wright homes), some of the colleges (i.e. Northwestern and U of C), or taken a trip to either Wisconsin or Indiana. In fact, the Lincoln Museum apparently just opened up while we were there, but Springfield is probably a good 3-4 hours away by car. Hope that helps.

Mar 8 2005	Excellent Hotel	My husband and I were truly pleased with our stay at the Homewood Suites in Downtown Chicago. It was in a great location and we had no problems finding our way around the area. We got a great rate which was quite fitting for all of the amenities and services that were provided. The staff was very friendly and helpful and it was a joy interacting with them. Our room was quite cozy and comfortable and we had a great veiw of the city from our room window. If we are ever in the Chicago area again we will surely be looking at Homewood Suites as our first choice.

Feb 2 2005	Very Nice Place	I stayed at Homewood Suites for a weekend in January. I was very impressed for the price that I paid. The staff was very friendly and the room was clean and larger than expected. Plus, I loved the fact that I could walk right across the street and straight into Norstrom's and it's attached mall. I have stayed at more "luxury" hotels in Chicago, that might provide a more pampered feel. However, you cannot beat the price of Homewood for the room size and location.

Jan 2 2005	A really good spot for the money	Our second visit taking our three grade school age children. Lived in Chi. for 10 years and know the neighborhood well. Hotel is easily accessed by car, and is about 4 blocks southwest of the major traffic messes in Streeterville and around Chicago and Michigan Ave. . The valet cost is average for the neighborhood - your car will be several blocks away. The doormen are helpful. The best thing about this place is the location. Steps from Mich Avenue, Nordstroms, an easy walk to Water Tower, American Girl, etc. Plenty of choices for restaurants within a block or two. If you want you can walk to Millenium Park - not too far. Hotel is one block from the subway. The rooms are 1980's vintage, but clean. Lots of room in the suites for a family, and the kitchen is nice to have if you have young ones. Actually a nice view on the higher floors. The lobby / front desk is always understaffed. The "free buffet" is mobbed if the hotel is full, but you can take your food in styrofoam containers back to your room if there are no tables. Nice coffee service all day with fruit, in the lobby. Access to the nice Crunch fitness center in the lobby is free, and it is very nice. The pool on the roof is small but has a beautiful view of the city. There is a small workout room on the top floor as well. PF Changs delivers room service, but save the tip and go down and pick it up yourself. Overall, nothing fancy, but nice enough with a great location. With the money you save go shopping at Nordstrom's mall.

Dec 8 2004	Great location but be prepared to walk!	We stayed at Homewood Suites-Chicago in early December 2004 so we could do some Christmas shopping and enjoy the lights on Michigan Avenue. This hotel has the perfect location for such a trip. Our room was a small suite and a maintenance man had to come move things around to pull out the couch for our kids, but the room was clean and don't they say it's Location, Location, Location. This hotel is within walking distance to nearly everything which is what we wanted. The complimentary breakfast is good and plentiful with eggs, fruit, sausage, etc. It was crowded, but we didn't have to wait. The only negative we encountered was the elevator. The hotel is 19 stories. We were on the 16th floor and the lobby/restaurant is on the 6th. With people checking out and going to breakfast, it was busy and one elevator was broken! There were many unhappy visitors that day and we ended up walking UP 10 flights and almost walked down all 16 after waiting at least 15 minutes for an elevator! That was the only really negative thing. They need to work on fixing this issue. Otherwise it was great!

Nov 30 2004	great place	this was a great location not too far from downtown or the Mag. mile.Our room was clean and very nice with a separate bedroom and a living area and kitchen (which we did not use)- too many great restuarants in chicago. The only slight problem we had was a breakfast- very crowded, but the hotel was very accomodating. we stayed for 4 nights and would go back again.

Nov 21 2004	Great value great stay 	We stayed here for a week in November when it was very busy in town due to many big conventions. Most nights the Homewood was booked full, but we had no problems or complaints. On the contrary, we moved rooms once with their help and little inconvenience.Rooms on the north side are spacious, much larger than the Embassy Suites or any downtown hotel rooms. Over 600 sq ft. We preferred the room on the south side, though smaller, because we liked its "feel" plus most rooms on the south sides offer great city views. The Embassy Suites and most downtown hotel rooms have almost no views. Having been in both, we preferred the Homewood to the Embassy though the Homewood cost less. The Embassy has better quality rooms (recently redone) whereas the Homewood shows a bit of wear (5 years old), however the Homewood Suites are bigger and have windows with views in both the L/R and bedroom. The Homewood also features a full kitchen instead of a small galley. It feels like a small apartment instead of a hotel.All staff were very helpful. The buffet breakfast was always well-stocked, right up til the last minute. The free light evening meals exceeded our expectation - not great entrees but okay, plus good salads, rolls and delicious cakes or pie, and wine or beer too! Chicago is very expensive to eat, so we saved a fortune on breakfast and dinners, by eating in a few days and treating ourselves out some other days.In contrast to earlier reviewers, the elevators were adequate, and always worked fine. Wireless high-speed internet is available for FREE, and local phone calls are FREE. WOW! If you dont have a card for your laptop, they lend you a wireless internet gateway. We used that and it worked flawlessly.They also have complimentary tea & coffee & fruit in the lobby 24/7. It's in a perfect location and yet it was very quiet.

Oct 23 2004	Homewood Suites a winner!	My husband and I stayed at the Homewood Suites by Hilton for a week beginning Oct. 14. We were very pleased with the spacious, clean suite. Other than that, the room was great! And the hotel is also very conveniently located, just one block from the subway. For a rate of $139/night (for a week stay), we feel the Homewood Suites are a great value.

Aug 26 2004	A big disappointment!	I would not stay at this hotel again. The location is great but we encountered quite a few problems. Aug 9 2004	Homewood Suites- Majorly Disappointing	This was a good location, but the hotel did not deliver what it promised. We visited July 28...a group of 6 women, 2 rooms,5 days. Another huge problem is that you must take elevator to floor 6 (lobby) then use your room card to get to floors. Stupid- anyone could access the hotel at that point. But half the time, one of only 2 elevators was not working, and we would spend 20 min downstairs waiting to go up. I walk, I would have easily taken steps to upper floors, but was NOT allowed. I liked having the kitchen and frig- though I would hesitate to return here again given the attitude of the staff. I don't think the amount you pay should have an impact on politeness of service staff, no matter where you are.

Aug 5 2004	Homewood Suites- A GREAT HOTEL	I stayed 4 nights at the Homewood Suites on Grand Avenue. It was an excellent location between Michigan and State. Jul 22 2004	Wow! what a deal!	My husband and I spent a night at the Homewood Suites, Chicago downtown. Such a deal! Jul 12 2004	Homewood Suites rock!	Just spent 5 great days with my spouse at the Homewood Suites in Chicago. We drove in from Louisiana and were able to check in a couple of hours early which we really appreciated. The staff were very friendly and efficient. The room was just as advertised and was very clean. The bed was very comfortable and having 2 TV's was a real plus. Nov 10 2009 	Girl's Weekend with American Girl	We take a yearly "Girl's Weekend. There were eight of us ranging in ages from eight to eighty. I mentioned that we were going to visit the American Girl Store as we have two girls with dolls. We arrived around noon and to our amazement, there were two hot pink star cookies with milk in each room! Waiting on the bed was a personal invitation to the girls to visit the store and a fold up bed for each one of the dolls as a complimentary gift to the girls. You can only imagine how excited the girls were.The hotel staff was great. The girls had a fun time in the pool then took their showers in the Athletic Club-they supplied everything from shampoo and conditioner to a blow dryer. One of the girls did not pack a toothbrush so we called the front desk and they sent up toothbrush and paste. We received "Red Carpet" treatment! Nov 4 2009 	Never again!	Well. I had thought that the InterContinental was an upscale chain, having stayed at the one in Hong Kong (formerly the Regent). I was mistaken. I stayed at this one for 2 days while attending a meeting and was very disappointed. The positives first: location, staff, lobby, food/drink. A Starbucks in the lobby. These were all fine if not better than fine. I suppose the $276/night was for these features.And then the negatives....The room was just deplorable. The Crowne Plaza in Minneapolis I stayed at last month was far better. I was in the "nonhistoric" side of the hotel--the room was tiny and in need of serious renovation. The bathroom was small, dingy, with peeling wallpaper, cheap or worn fixtures, scratchy towels, and sink faucets that went in the wrong direction. The bed was fine, however, comfortable with good linens. The fee to use the hotel gym was another unpleasant little surprise. I don't even know where to begin with that one, as I have not encountered that problem before. At what is basically $300/night, it seems insulting to ask hotel guests to pay extra for that.I guess I was shocked at the discrepancy between the attention to the nice lobby area, public spaces/services, customer service (excellent at the front desk and at the curb), and the very poor conditions of the room. I understand that this is a big city and that the hotel is in a great location, but I felt like I had been deceived. There are plenty of hotels to choose from in Chicago. Next time, even if I have to spend a little more, I will go elsewhere.

Oct 11 2009 	Great place for kids	Easy to find, kid friendly. The pool was hard to get to, but it was nice.

Oct 8 2009 	Beauty and excellent service...right in the center of the Magnificent Mile.	A friend and I flew into Chicago for a "girls weekend away" and stayed at the InterContinental. You probably already know about the famous swimming pool. Our room had two comfortable queen beds, a desk, a recliner, very nice sized flat-screen television, in-room coffee maker (small) with coffee and tea, and terry bathrobes. No fridge or microwave. The window actually opened! Elevators were fast and never a long wait. The wonderful concierge provided exceptional service, directing us to a great Italian restaurant only blocks away (and getting us a reservation so we didn't have to wait for a table ... and there were LOTS of people waiting for tables) one night and a great Thai restaruant and Blues bar another night. He also helped us get reservations to the House of Blues Gospel Brunch on Sunday. Couldn't believe that the food was so affordable!  We took the El from the airport to within 3 blocks of our hotel - for $2.25! Sure beats the cost of a taxi! We walked everywhere...including to the Chicago river for a boat tour highlighting the skyline's architecture, out to Navy Pier to the Stained Glass Museum, to the Chicago Institute of Art, and, of course, to the park to see the "bean" - Cloud Gate - sculpture and eat a real Chicago hot dog. Every evening we returned to a clean room with fresh complimentary toiletries for a rest before heading out to hear live music. We didn't have time to check out the hotel's own Wine and Chocolate bar (what a great combination!). The only "negative" I can think of regarding this hotel was that although we tried to "be green" by hanging up our towels to be used a 2nd day, as the placard in the marble-tiled bathroom suggested, the maids put fresh towels in every day.

Aug 29 2009 	Extra Charges is only thing keeping this from a 5 star	I have stayed here before and I love this hotel. It is so beautiful and in a great location. I visit Chicago yearly for a Leadership Summit and I stay here or the Embassy Suites depending on which is offered.First the bad, everything is extra here. Internet, fitness center and just about everything else. I never leave home without the laptop and work while I'm away but I did not purchase internet at the hotel. The headquarters hotel that the conference was at had free internet hot spots so I took my netbook there and worked between sessions and at the end of the day. I just can't see paying $12.95 a day when I'm only using it an hour or two.I did not get to tour the hotel this time even though I swore I would but I did check out the pool and it was beautiful. The security guard recommended that you go to the old section and start on the 8th floor and walk all the way down checking out each floor. Hopefully next year.This trip I did get to see rooms in both the old and new sections. My traveling partner was in the new section in room 1062. The room was small but beautiful and very clean. If they took the couch out it would feel like you had a lot more room. She was very happy with her room.I stayed in the historic section in room 2415. My room wasn't ready when we got there but we were early and they were very busy. It was ready about 1/2 hour after the promised time, about 4 pm. My room was large and had a very big bathroom with a separate shower. Again this hotel is very clean. Water was $6.95 a bottle and the mini bar was way overpriced even for a hotel. A stop at Walgreens fixed that.The bed was comfy and once I got to sleep I never woke up at night or heard any of the neighbors. The room was just plain wonderful. I had a king bed and there were 4 big fluffy pillows on the bed. My husband would have loved it. I need a firm pillow and always travel with my contour pillow. I had a semi-river view and it was pretty. There was a great old building across from my room that I had a view of and it was nice.Finally a hotel with good TV channels. I was so tired at the end of the day I couldn't even read so I enjoyed falling asleep to the TV. The person I traveled with this year kept me pretty busy and I got to see a little more of Chicago then I usually do.One item noted by myself and my friend was that even though we hung the towels up to reuse they replaced them. If you are not going to conserve water by letting the guests reuse towels then don't put the little cards in that say you will. Good selection of soap and shampoo and stuff. They offered both bar soap and bath gel. I hate when hotels cheap out and only offer bar soap. There is a blow drier there for those who like to know. I didn't use it so don't know how strong it is.There is also a coffee maker in the bathroom that makes the little pots of coffee. I did use this every morning before hitting Starbucks.All the hotel staff was helpful and friendly. Starbucks was not crowded in the morning this trip as in the past so we had a nice coffee on our walk to the conference.All in all if you want to stay in a beautiful hotel in Chicago whose prices are pretty much par with the rest, stay here. My first choice is the Embassy Suites because of the free internet and breakfast which saves my travel budget but for beauty you can not compare to this hotel.

Aug 24 2009 	Great Location but Watch Out for Nickel and Diming!	This was my third stay at this hotel. Here's the good. The location is unbeatable, putting the Loop, Aert Institute, Navy Pier, River North restaurants, and Magnificent Mile shopping, within blocks. The buffet breakfast is of high quality with made to order eggs and omelettes, warm quiches, bread pudding, and a meat of the day, The rooms are comfortable and elegant, if not quite luxuriousHere's the not so good. Parking was $53, not the quoted $50 when I made the reservation. I made the reservation through the property, as an Intercontinental Ambassador, but I did not receive the requisite upgrade. (Maybe I should have used Priceline and paid a lot less if this is how they treat "Ambassadors"). When I complained, the hotel did offer a suite in the less desirable new wing, instead of our two connecting rooms, but the bed configuration was unsuitable. Free internet which was offered as part of the Ambassador package was not available. The hotel offered a free in-room movie instead. Although the pool was free, the fitness center imposed a $12 daily charge (or $16 per stay) On departure, we discovered that we had been charged a gratuity for the breakfasts (which were included in our package). We had left cash gratuities each morning and were dismayed at this charge, which was imposed without our knowledge. The hotel also charged for one day's breakfast, claiming we had eaten after 11, nearly two hours after we had left the hotel. All these charges were removed, but we had to get past front desk staff, and speak to a supervisor. The whole experience left a very bad taste in our mouths. Also, it cost me over $20 to print four boarding passes and check my e-mail in the business center/So go with your eyes open and your hands on your wallet. Ask for the historic tower. Don't bring a car unless absolutely necessary,

Aug 3 2009 	Beautiful Hotel	Firstly there is a comment regarding this hotel from a guest that paid $100 through hotwire and thought they paid too much...If you think a $100 is too much to pay to stay on Michigan Avenue at the InterContinental then you are better off staying at a Best Western out at the airport, maybe that would suit your lifestyle. Jul 17 2009 	Very Nice	We only stayed here one night and it was btwn this & the Swissotel. but I;m glad I picked this one. Located on the "Magnigficent Mle" & in walking distance to just about all the attractions. We stayed in the Historic towers (room 1404 which faced North Michigan) , where the rooms are larger then in the main bldg. The beds were very comfortable as were the pillows, and the sheets very softs as well. The a/c worked fine which was climate controlled. The bathroom has a separate tub & shower.. and very spacious as well.. the lighting in there could have been a little better though. We checked out the pool,,, but didnt use it.  It is an older hotel.. and I didnt find the furnishings outdated, I thought they complimented the hotel. They did had flat screen TVS in the room.  Checking in was a bit slow... only 2 people behind the counter.. and one took forever with this couple.. but the other guy worked very quickly. We did the express check out... (at 6:30am.. there were quite a few people in line) You don't even need to rent a car- you can pick up the CTA Blue Line train system at Ohare Airport & for $2.25 you can take it all the way in to the city. We had a car (we had driven to Indianapolis the day before for the Indy Car Race Experience) and had planned to drive it back to the airport on the day we left.. but there was an Avis car rental place a few blocks from the hotel.. so we dropped it off early & took the train in .. very convenient & cheap.. considering all the hotels in the city charge you alot to park ($53 a night at the Intercontinental.. which is comprable to all the others). I would definatley stay here again if we ever come back. Chicago is a beautiful city & there is alot to do there. We only had one day there to see stuff and would like to return to see more. Definately check out the Sears (now Willis) Tower, but go early.. you will wait a long time if you go later in the day. Also Millenium Park... The Wendella Boat tour (90 minute one) was good also. Giordanos for Deep Dish Pizza.. something you have to try (especially if you are from the NY/NJ area).

Jul 17 2009 	Magnificant Moments on Magnicant Mile Chicago Intercontinental	I have travelled to Chicago a few times for work and always try and stay a few extra days but when a friend of mine suggested we go for a girls four day vacation I immediately thought of this great city. We booked the hotel online through hotwire and received a great rate. We took a limo from the airport and from the moment we stepped out of the car we were greeted with such warmth and service. We were early for check in but wanted to walk to Pane Caldo (my favourite) and the bellman directed us to the check in desk where we mentioned that we would like to stay in the historic tower. I had joined online the priority club (idid not have any points at this point) and the very friendly representative upgraded our room and put us in the historic tower at no extra charge. This was accomodating considering we were already paying about 60% below the room rates. Our room would be ready for us after lunch and they stored all of our bags promptly. Our room was beautfiul on the 12th floor overlooking Michigan avenue-two nice double beds -the most comfortable ever, comfy robes,beatiful entrance way , desk for working (i managed to bring my laptop to do some work as well) and they called up to ask if were happy with our room. We had purchased some champagne at a store and asked for some glasses to be sent-not only were they at our door withing minutes they called to make sure we received them. I logged on immediately to the wireless and they only charge me for one day and we stayed three. When we made a few errors with ordering a movie separately at different times to watch-they simply took it off our bill. We ordered room service once for late nite munchies and the service was fast and the food good especially after a lot of champagne and music at the Drake-i do not have a problem with paying more for somehting at 3:00am-they are a hotel and are in the business of making money! The hotel staff were always courteous and friendly and made an effort to make our stay the best we have ever had anywhere. Both my friend and I have done a lot of travelling (I have also lived in the islands) and we must honestly say that the Intercontinental Chicago is the best we have ever stayed anywhere in the world. This is the only place i will stay when i go to Chicago! Keep up the great service and staff ICC.

Jul 17 2009 	Location luxury and service.... The Intercontinental nailed it!	I stayed with my wife and brother and his fiance (he proposed while we were out there) at the Intercontinental in July 2009. I've read some somewhat critical reviews of this place, but we had a wonderful time. I'll give you my thoughts below:PROS:- Location - The location is really perfect for a downtown Chicago experience. The hotel is located on Michigan Ave., a about 100 yards north of the Chicago River. So it's smack dab right in the middle of the Magnificient Mile. You could walk most every place you wanted to go, or you could hop on a train to get to further flung locations.- Hotel - The Intercontinental was very well-appointed, and high-end, yet comfortable. The rooms had flat-screen HDTVs (but only had 2 HD channels), down comforter and pillows, the bathroom was modern and had quality toiletries. The design of the room was also modern, yet comfortable. There was obligitory $8 bottle of water and basket of $6 candy bars. Who actually buys this? - Service - The serviece at the hotel was great. We checked in a little early, and they had us in a room with 2 double beds. We asked for a king, and they told us that unfortunatley that they didn't have one ready, but took my number and would call me when it was ready. We went and had lunch, and then within an hour they gave me a call and told me it was ready. Throughout the rest of the stay, everyone from the front desk staff to the bell staff to the consierge was nothing but friendly and professional, without any of that big-city snobbery.- Ammenities - There was a very nice looking wine, cheese and chocolate specialty restaurant in the hotel that we didn't use, and the in-hotel bar was very nice. In addition, there is a Starbucks in the hotel, a nice way to get a light, cheap breakfast, thereby avoiding a high-cost breakfast.CONS:- Fitness Center - The only complaint I have is that the fitness center was like $25 a day to use for hotel guests, and the fitness center was only an OK hotel gym, not even on par for that much a day. The pool was free to hotel guests, and while I recommend that everyone take a look at it (it looks like a pool frozen in time during the 1920's), it is only for swimming laps, so unless you are a pretty hardcore swimmer, no pool for you.All in all, we had an absolutely wonderful time at the Intercontinental, and we will go back again if we have the chance.

Jul 12 2009 	Waaaay out of it's league	Fiancee and I stayed here recently (Jun/09) to check out apartments in South loop area and for a bit of romantic R-and-R. (Didn't quite do it for us for latter purpose). Booked through Hotwire (maybe that was the mistake), which rated this at 4.5 stars (wish I had a BS detector). Upon arrival, discovered only one parking option exists... valet, which runs $53 per day. Ok, fine. Then, at check-in, lady told us room we were getting was great with spectacular views... lie. Come to find out, room was musty smelling, worn-looking (and I don't mean the decor) and very dark. Serious need for a remodeling/redecorating, at least for our room. As for the "spectacular view", one small window in the corner with a partial view of Chicago River and Michigan Ave; what a joke. Then discovered hot water fixture in sink was broken. Called to report it; all they could offer was that they'd send someone to take a look at it... no offer for room change, voucher, nada, not even a thank you for having reported it. Noise from hallway other room doors opening/closing was very apparent and annoying. Felt a bit like we were in a cruise ship, as the nickel-and-dime approach to a few of the amenities seems to be the other modus operandi at this hotel (following the trend of the big-chain hotel industry it would seem); $12.95/day for wireless, for example. Even though we booked through Hotwire (somewhat of a deal, relatively speaking), based on what we observed and experienced, this hotel does not deserve to be rated higher than 3.5 (4 maybe, but that's stretching it) EVEN at the price we paid (just under $200). Other than that, service was just "okay", nothing special. Hotels in this tier really need to take that extra step make you want to return or at least attempt to provide a memorable stay. In this regard, the Intercontinental just falls flat and is way out of its league... it simply offers nothing that to make it, or your stay, stand out. Take this together with the above-mentioned demerits, and I would have to recommend that you seriously consider staying elsewhere. Prospective travelers (and hotels, for that matter) can (and do) much better than this, especially in this area and price range. I'm somewhat disappointed with Hotwire as well... I've had good luck with them in the past, but they have never been quite this far off-the-mark in terms of rating and overall value.

Jun 3 2009 	Ideal Hotel For Chicago Holiday	We stayed for 7 nights in the Intercontinental & found it an excellent hotel in one of the best locations especially for first time visitors to Chicago.We got an great rate through Hotwire & were delighted with our corner room on the 8th floor with views towards the river down Michigan Ave.Some previous reviews mentioned the rooms were small but we were quite happy & everything was to a high standard and very clean.We were spoiled for choice with the selection of shops & restaurants all within walking distance of the hotel ,did some serious retail therapy in Eddie Bowers directly across the road ,great bargains.Five minute walk to the boarding area for Wendella lake & river tours -great trip,10min walk to the fab Millenium park,5 minutes to the House Of Blues for a great Sunday brunch -little touristy but had great fun, 3 blocks to the Red line metro which will get you to the theatre district in 5 minutes & Wrigley Field or Celluar Field in 15 minutes,directly beside the stops for the free trolley to Navy Pier so we really couldnt have asked to be in a better location. Starbucks on the ground floor very handy for an early coffee & a nice local bar Blackies directly behind the hotel.Because there are so many choices close to the hotel we never tried the hotel bars or restaurants .The only slight negative is the excessive hotel charge for wifi & its not free in Starbucks either because it is owned by the hotel but just pop down to the apple store on Michigan.

Mar 10 2009 	Romantic gem on Michigan Avenue but be prepared to walk for better dining 	We could not have asked for a nicer room, better service, or a better location for $125 a night. It was only a $8.00 cab ride from Union Station, too, which by the way I would highly recommend taking a train to Chicago. Parking prices seemed ridiculous & the driving was very crazy! We stayed in the Historic Tower King Room with a view of Michigan Avenue. The room was luxurious & romantic. It would have been nice to have a CD player in the room. And P.S. ladies- do not use the complimentary lotion, it smells very bad, like old playdough or something! But those are my only two very minor complaints. We didn't use the pool area but we checked it out- a very nice large pool but for lap swimming only. We didn't see a sauna or whirlpool, either. Every single staff member we encountered was extremely professional & courteous. They had 2 employees who worked right outside the door loading & unloading luggage, hailing cabs, & they even escorted me to the door under an umbrella the night we returned & it was raining! Now that's service! You must try the Passiontini at the bar by the entrance- $13 but the best drink of the weekend! Drinking is VERY expensive in Chicago- don't think you will find cheap drinks- we didn't & we went to lots of different style bars. The dining options are very limited for this being such a large hotel. We previewed the breakfast menu & they were charging $14 for 2 pancakes! Nothing with it, just 2 pancakes! We found a great diner right around the corner with unbelievable breakfast at a much better value (Mary's Cafe), pretty much every breakfast was $10.95, we had 4 different things & they were all super delicious! If you go right out of the hotel there is a set of stairs that takes you down under Michigan Avenue- keep walking straight from the bottom of the steps about 2 blocks, on the right is Mary's. You will pass the Reagle Beagle which has to be one of your nighttime stops- it ended up being our favorite bar. Very low keyed, great food, great atmosphere, great 80's decor & music. Not the songs that make you roll your eyes- the ones that make you say "I've got to put this on my ipod!!" You must try the Brady Brunch Punch, $10 each but soooo good! We had the boneless buffulo tenders one night with fries & they were great. Other than those 2 places near the hotel, nothing really stood out- you've got to walk further for more options. Couldn't ever find the popcorn shop that everyone raves about, but while we were looking we discovered that Hubbard Street would be a great afternoon bar hopping street. Someone else told me Rush Street has lots of bars, too. Unfortunately we found out about these on our last morning :( We needed a late check out & it was absolutely no problem getting it, even free of charge. So all in all this was an amazing hotel, but be prepared to walk for nightlife & dining.

I have been to just about all of the 4 star hotels in the area and I have to say there are many which are better than the Intercontinental and cost a little less. If you are not concerned with the quality regarding your room, this review might not be important. First of all, valet has gone up to 53 bucks a day. Apparently, they have to run all the way to the Navy Pier to get your car so you will be waiting a little longer than usual. I waited about a half hour. Now lets get tot he real disappointment: The rooms. I was incredibly peeved when I walked into my room. It was so tiny I kept bumping my knees on the furniture when I was moving my suitcases around. Both my suitcases would not even fit in the closet so I have to cramp them in which made it a hassle to get my clothes out. I have been in 2 star hotel rooms that looked nicer than this. There was a little cat hair on a red velore like love seat, with cheap, really stiff cushions. I am not saying the room was dirty but it certainly was not spotless either. There were quite a few holes in the sheets as well. Sleeping was impossible due to the loud heating system. I called the front desk and they immediately sent someone to look at it. He sort of giggled and said that there was nothing he could do because it was supposed to be that loud. I couldn not believe it. I'm sure they get many complaints about the heating systems. All in all the staff is friendly, the food is pretty good, However, there are many other hotels with comparable prices and much better quality rooms, service, and ambiance.

Feb 22 2009 	Amazing once again	My husband and I stayed at the Intercontinental for the second time on Valentines day this year. We were celebrating both our February birthdays and Valentines day. We had been upgraded to an executive suite and let me tell you it was fabulous! The room had two bathrooms which made getting ready really convenient and the comfy couch in the outer room was perfect for relaxing and watching T.V. I actually wanted to spend time in this hotel room. My favorite part of staying at this hotel is the staff. They are truly helpful and really went out of there way to make sure our stay was enjoyable. From the bell man who first helped with our bags to the very pleasant and kind front desk staff, we were made to feel like very special guests. It is so nice to spend time in a place where people greet you with smiles and kind words even when just answering a question over the phone. We will definately be back!

Feb 20 2009 	Great location and decent quality for the price	I booked package deal with airfare and hotel. I was pleased to find this hotel was right in the heart of Michigan Avenue. I thought the decor was updated in the room I was in and liked that there was a Starbucks attached in lobby. Also, check out the pool area (even if you don't swim) it is very cool architecture. I had a great trip, enjoyed the staff, the bar, the room, etc. Room service was pretty good TOO! I would recommend this for several reasons but best of all is the location. Can't wait to visit again!

Feb 17 2009 	Great Chicago Hotel Experience @ Hotel Inter-Continental	I work alot and i'm not able to get away on vacation with my children to much. so i work in the chicago area and wanted alittle getaway just for the weekend , so i chose the intrercontental for just that. and its just what we needed for that little break. We had a great time there .went swimming ,the pool was beautiful.And everyone at the hotel was so accommodating.I will be returning for another stay .

Feb 15 2009 	Horrible Hotel	To avoid saying what others have already said, just don't stay at this hotel unless you're looking for a super cheap hotel in the city.My fiance and I booked a room here for Valentine's Day to get away from the daily grind but little did we know how disappointed we would be. The hotel staff was mediocre, decor was old and the hotel smelled stale! The ceilings are so short, so if you're even close to being 6 feet or taller, you're going to bump your head....seriously! The gym was smaller than most peoples bathrooms and if you think you're going to do anything other than run on the treadmill, you can forget it! They charge you $12 to workout and there wasn't ONE weight to lift, a resistance ball or room to stretch....simply horrbile! On top of that, we had to wait 10 minutes every time we wanted to use the elevator because they were so slow. The ice machine was on the 7th floor, so needless to say, we wasted a lot of time just getting ice.Overall, this hotel was pitiful! My fiance and I both agreed that our time would've been better spent at home. We live downtown already and just wanted to spend the night at a really nice hotel in the city and do some shopping on Michigan Ave. If it weren't for the location, this hotel wouldn't be in business! It wasn't even worth the $112 we spent to book it on Priceline. In the end, I guess you get what you pay for....

Feb 12 2009 	Great Location Great Experience	Stayed at the InterContinental based on a recommendation from a co-worker. It was an excellent choice! It's in a great location right on Michigan Avenue, the room was very nice, and the staff was extremely accomodating! On my next trip to Chicago, I'll definitely be staying at the InterContinental.

Feb 10 2009 	Girls Weekend and the Intercontinental	I booked a one night stay at the Intercontinental for a Saturday night so that me and my girls could have a night out in downtown Chicago. The Intercontinental is in a fabulous location. It is walking distance or a quick cab ride to just about anything in the downtown area. I booked a room with my cousin directly through the hotel. We were given a promotional package at the time of booking that included a room upgrade to the historical tower and a $50 food/beverage credit to use at the hotel restaurants/bars. When we arrived at the hotel, we were told that there were no more rooms available in the historic tower that had 2 double beds, even though that was guaranteed ahead of time with our reservation. I was disappointed that at such a nice hotel that things like this happen. They offered us a room with a king bed in the historic tower, but we decided to take a room with 2 double beds in the main tower. The room was very nice, but very small. The bathroom was nice, but there was a very narrow doorway to get into the bathroom, which I thought was a little odd. We used our food credit for the breakfast buffet in the morning. The buffet was excellent, although quite pricey. The buffet was $24.95 per person, but the upside to that is that you are overlooking Michigan Avenue. I would recommend the splurge for breakfast - it was a nice relaxing way to spend the morning. In all, I would recommend this hotel for a night or 2 at a time, but if you are going to spend a lot of time in the room, I would recommend looking elsewhere since it is quite a small room. I work in downtown Chicago and my job demands that I know the ins and outs of the hotels in the downtown area. I've never been in the Intercontinental before my stay there, and I booked at that hotel because of it's location and also to check it out for work. It's a very nice hotel, but there are many nice hotels in downtown Chicago, and this one is not any more special than any of the others. If you are able to get a good deal at this hotel (under $200 a night), then I would recommend it.

Feb 7 2009 	Great location unique wine bar can't wait to go back.	Shame the pool was closed, but offered use of pool in another hotel across the road. Can't fault the location, central to everything. Especially enjoyed the wine&cheese bar downstairs, which we visited for a drink before heading out - excellent staff there.We were offered a free tour of the old building but never got around to it, will save it for next time!

Feb 2 2009 	Whoever designed and installed the plumbing should be shot	Whoever designed and/or installed the plumbing should be shot. I was on the 37th floor and the shower was unusable. There was so little water pressure that the shower stream couldn't hit the opposite wall of the shower. Moreover, the temperature couldn't be adjusted. After 30 seconds, I gave up and took a bath. I wasn't happy with the slowness of the flow from the bathroom sink faucet, plus the sink didn't drain properly. If I had managed to use the shower, the light in the shower was burned out. The bathroom scale didn't work at all. The Internet service was slow for $12.95 a day. The maid failed to refill my supply of coffee and cream/sugar so I had to call downstairs for them. The decor of the room was nice and the bed was comfortable. Front desk personnel were friendly and the bellmen helpful.

Jan 26 2009 	Pleasantly Surprised by the InterContinental	My husband and I decided to use Hotwire to book our one night stay in downtown Chicago to celebrate our anniversary. We choose a $110/nightly 4.5 star rating from Hotwire and they then told us that we would be staying at the InterContinenal and I must admit I was a little bummed as I was hoping for a smaller, boutique style hotel. When we arrived Saturday afternoon the lobby was bustling with energy and there were many people floating in and out of the bar. We made our way to the front desk and were nicely greeted by a front desk attendant who was extremely friendly. I was carrying a bottle of wine that we had brought with us and she noticed it, jokingly commenting, "Oh that was so nice of you to bring that for us!" She then asked if we were there for a special occasion and I told her that we were celebrating our anniversary. A few clicks on the keyboard later she told us that she had applied several upgrades to our reservation. This is very uncommon given that we used a 3rd party source to book our stay. Our room, suite really, was in the Historic Tower on the 34th floor. There was a large bathroom with a tub set underneath a large window with an awesome view of the city and a separate glass enclosed shower. The bedroom was spacious with a king bed, desk, couch, and entertainment center. There were also two large windows in the bedroom. Overall we were very impressed with the room, given that we had only paid $110. My husband really liked the bed (very firm) but I found it to be a bit lumpy and uncomfortable. The tub beneath the window was nice but it was just a regular size and not large enough to really lay down and relax in. The maid service was very quick to bring extra towels when we needed them and there was a button system on the door to let them know when not to disturb. The decorative style in the room was a bit dated, but not too cheesy or old looking. Sunday when we checked out we were assisted by the front desk manager who was, again, extremely friendly and courteous. We grabbed a Starbucks (nicely located within the lobby area) and took our bags to the bell stand. The bell staff (working the desk) were by far the least helpful/most rude staff at the hotel. They didn't smile and seemed pretty annoyed that we wanted to store our bags for a few hours while we walked around downtown. The only real problem we had was retrieving our car from the valet (that was ridiculously priced at $50). We waited about 30 minutes and finally went back to the valet desk where we had paid to get our car out. The woman had forgotten to give one of the runners our keys and our car had never been sent for. Fortunately we weren't in a hurry and so they went to get our car and she immediately apologized, took responsibility, and took my husband with her to refund the $50 fee. We were thrilled with her response and professionalism. Overall the InterContinental is a nice place to stay in the city. Would we pay more than we did to stay there again, nah, too many other great places for the same great price.

Jan 25 2009 	Intercontinental Chicago--* World Class!	The Intercontinental Chicago is World Class--at amazingly low rates!
